author: vinsmoke_42234
content: Hello guys, does eip-4844  support range proof of blob data to KZG commitment?

author: jtraglia
content: <@1152594466931228812> could you be a little more specific?

author: vinsmoke_42234
content: i want to prove a subset of blob data belong to a specific address (that address posts blob data on chain), but i have so far found no inclusion  proof of blob data.

author: jtraglia
content: Gotcha thanks. I don't believe eip4844 directly supports this, though you may be able to do it yourself. For example, if you structure part of the blob data as a Merkle tree, you could generate your own inclusion proofs. But that doesn't feel like a great solution.

author: vinsmoke_42234
content: <@592004585506340885> thanks bro, I did see some blogs that said it could be done with KZG commitment, but I couldn't find any technical documentation.

author: jtraglia
content: It might be possible. Hopefully someone else can chime in. Good question though.

author: jtraglia
content: So I was wrong. I forgot that you can generate proofs for individual elements in a blob with `compute_kzg_proof(blob, z) -> (proof, y)`. I think this is what you want. This blog does a great job of explaining it: https://pat.net/ckzg/

author: vinsmoke_42234
content: <@592004585506340885> really appreciated that bro. I just confused about what z or y stands for in the formula of KZG, I should learn more about zero knowledge.

author: kevaundray
content: Here is a hackmd by lion on it: https://hackmd.io/@dapplion/blob_sharing#Appendix-KZG-commitment-proofs-for-data-subset

author: vinsmoke_42234
content: <@427491045308235776> Thanks, even if the KZG commitment can be used to verify a field element in blob, but it costs 50000 gas (by using precompiled contract: 0x0a). I am not sure  if 0x0a is  compatible with proving multiple elements. You mentioned hackmd (https://hackmd.io/@dapplion/blob_sharing#Appendix-KZG-commitment-proofs-for-data-subset) said that using pairing check to prove a subset belong to a commitment, the pairing check (bls12381.PairingCheck ?) is still in the next upgrade plan and has not been activated on the mainnet.

author: kevaundray
content:
If you use 0x0a as is, then you would need to call it for every ~32 bytes of data that you want to prove is a subset of a particular blob. 

Yep; EIP2537 introduces the pairing check that is noted in that hackmd since the curve being used is bls12-381. I checked the EIP and it says the cost of a pairing is `43_000*k + 65_000` This is out of sync with 0x0a so I imagine that that will get updated
